title: Metro trains bypassing Capitol South as police investigate stabbing of juvenile
text:
Newsham said the injured boy was in surgery. Three Metro employees came to the aid of the boy, who emerged from the train after the stabbing and approached the fare gates, Newsham said.

“Hats off to them for trying to save this kid’s life,” he said of the Metro workers.

AD

Chuck Decker, 20, an American University student, said he entered the station moments after the stabbing. He said the victim was inside the fare gate on the ground and seemed to be bleeding profusely from the neck area.

AD

Newsham said it wasn’t known what school or schools the teens attended, but noted D.C. Public Schools weren’t in session Friday. He said investigators are combing through Metro surveillance video.

“We have video technicians going through that right now, so we should have a real clear picture of what happened,” Newsham said.

Police had said they were searching for a teenage girl in connection with the stabbing, described as 14 years old, black and weighing about 100 pounds, with short dreadlocks and wearing a black, hooded sweatshirt with khaki pants.

AD

Newsham said he couldn’t explain a recent spike in violence across the city that included five homicides since Tuesday.

“It’s hard to say what’s going on,” he said. “None of the cases we’ve seen in Ward 6 are tied together.”

The Capitol South Metro station was closed as police investigated the stabbing in the 300 block of 1st Street SE. Trains on Metro’s Orange, Blue and Silver lines were bypassing the station.

AD

Metro officials recommended commuters use the Eastern Market or Federal Center SW stations as alternates. Transit officials said the station was likely to remain closed for some time.

The Capitol South Metro station is less than two blocks south of the U.S. Capitol grounds and across the street from the Cannon House Office Building.

AD
description: Police were searching for a 14-year-old girl in connection with the incident.
